Electrocatalytic oxidation of methanol is crucial for the transition to clean energy and the effective utilization of renewable sources. The strategy to develop efficient electrocatalysts with improved efficiency and durability for the methanol oxidation (MOR) reaction is essential to enable the widespread usage of direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs). This research proposes a novel, eco-friendly single-step procedure for preparing a highly efficient bimetallic platinum-palladium (Pt-Pd)/reduced graphene oxide-potassium iodide (RGO-KI) (PP@RGO-KI) nanocomposite sheet for electrocatalytic methanol oxidation. The method employs a chemical reduction strategy via a hydrothermal reaction, utilizing ascorbic acid (AA) as a simple and green reducing agent. The synergistic effects of Pt and Pd nanoparticles, along with enhanced electron transfer enabled by RGO, were examined by calculating the mass-normalized current densities (jmass) at 0.631 V for Pt/C, Pd/RGO, Pt-Pd/RGO (PP@RGO), Pt/RGO & PP@rGO-KI were 0.131, 0.171, 0.215, 0.421, and 0.526 mA/µg-Pt, respectively. Furthermore, the specific current densities (jspecific) at 0.631 V were determined as follows: 0.298 mA/cm² for Pd/RGO, 0.337 mA/cm² for Pt/C, 0.341 mA/cm² for Pt/RGO, 0.534 mA/cm² for PP@RGO, and 0.628 mA/cm² for PP@RGO-KI. In additionally, the If/Ib values exhibited the following trend: PP@RGO-KI (1.72) > PP@RGO (1.54) > Pt/RGO (1.04) > Pt/C (1.01) > Pd/RGO (0.89), signifying that PP@RGO-KI is effective in preventing surface poisoning effects. The excellent electrocatalytic efficiency of the PP@RGO-KI, coupled with its facile and rapid manufacturing method, suggests significant potential for advancing DMFCs. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Fuel cell catalyst Methyl oxidation reaction (MOR) Hydrogen production Pt-Pd supported catalyst Energy conversion Electrocatalysts Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Combustion of traditional fossil fuels, including that of gasoline and diesel presents environmental problems in modern day society and leads to an increase in green-house gases pollution. In recent days supercapacitors, solar cells, batteries, and fuel cells are examples of energy storage technologies that have been used to lower the negative effects of these problems [1–3]. Amongst them fuel cells are the effective energy renovation tools when it comes to effectively transforming chemical energy from the burning of a small amount of fuel molecules into electrical energy [4,5]. Fuel cells are effective substitute to fossil fuels for energy resources, specifically renewable energy, that alter chemical energy to electrical energy through a catalytic reaction [6,7]. Recently, direct methanol (DMFCs) fuel cells and direct ethanol (DEFCs) fuel cells are recognized as a favorable alternative to address challenges related to energy storage, safety, low cost, and non-toxicity [8,9]. The inherent characteristics of the anode mostly influence fuel cell performance. Additionally, the unavoidable poisoning effect of CO intermediates compromises the electrocatalytic performance of catalysts used in the MOR. Therefore, to tackle this challenge and further improve catalyst efficiency, researchers are working to improve catalytic performance and anti-poisoning capabilities [10,11]. Electrocatalysts that are economical, highly stable, shows large surface area and effective in harsh environment are essential for developing MOR [12,13]. Up to now, Pt based catalysts are the benchmark electrocatalysts due to their high electrocatalytic activity. However, Pt is more expensive because it is scarce, and Pt-based catalysts have instability problems due to CO poisoning [14–16]. Consequently, there are now major drawbacks in the way of the various applications of Pt-based catalysts. In MOR under alkaline solutions, Pd based catalysts demonstrate exceptional catalytic efficacy and durability [17,18]. They are less vulnerable to the effects of CO owing to their ideal d-band centers. Pd is more affordable than Pt, despite both possessing similar face-centered cubic structures and exceptionally high lattice matching [19]. Notably, the hydrogen absorption energy, expressed as Gibbs free energy (ΔGH), is only slightly below zero for Pt, whereas Pd (ΔGH) is close to - 0.13 eV. Interestingly, combining Pt with Pd results in an elevation of (ΔGH) compared to Pd and Pt alone [20,21]. As a result, Pd and Pt together can benefit from the Pt–Pd synergistic effect, enhance the stability and catalytic performance of MOR. The catalysts properties and durability are significantly enhanced by the support, offering additional catalytic sites, and optimizing noble metal utilization to improve overall catalyst activity. Additionally, the O2-containing functional groups on the support strengthen the metal-support interaction, enhancing catalytic durability [22]. The RGO, with its abundant specific surface area and high conductivity, is a significantly assessed support for electrocatalysts, finding widespread applications in catalysis, energy harvesting, fuel cells, & biosensing [23–25]. RGO-supported noble metal catalysts exhibit distinct advantages, including enhanced catalytic properties, prolonged durability, and resistance to CO poisoning [26]. In this work, a novel hybrid composite comprising of Pt-Pd NPs (PP NPs) deposited on RGO, with and without the addition of KI, was fabricated using a distinctive chemical reduction-assisted hydrothermal approach in the existence of AA. The addition of KI to the fabrication reaction system can impact the precursor's reduction rate as well as control the catalyst's surface composition via its complexation capability. This regulation allows for the creation of a bi-metallic Pt-Pd hybrid catalyst with a crystal structure [27]. This composite was employed for the MOR process. The PP@RGO-KI composite exhibited drastically enhancement in electrocatalytic activity and stability towards MOR. Notably, it achieved a superior mass activity of 0.526 mA/µg-Pt, specific area current densities (jspecific) of 0.628 mA/cm², and an oxidation peak current to reduction peak current ratio (If/Ib) of 1.72. The enhanced performance of the PP@RGO-KI electrocatalyst can be due to its larger electrochemical surface area (ECSA), abundant catalytic active sites, and the synergy effects between Pt & Pd NPs. Additionally, the use of RGO ensures high electrical conductivity, facilitating rapid electron transfer between the catalyst and electrolyte solution. This study effectively demonstrates the fabrication of a hybrid composite to improve the catalytic activity of the DMFCs. The current density of the PP/RGO-KI catalyst in comparison with existing similar catalysts in Table 1 . 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Pt(C2H3O2)4 (99%) and Pd(CH3COO)2 (99%) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich Corporation, India. The following materials were obtained from Merck, India: NaNO3 (99.5%), KMnO4 (99%), CH3OH (99.9%), ascorbic acid, Nafion solution, graphite powder (+200 mesh), H2SO4(98%), 30% H2O2(99%), HCl (99%), and KI(99.5%). Throughout the experiment distilled water (DW) was used. 2.2 Synthesis of the PP@RGO-KI nanocomposite sheet by hydrothermal approach A modified version of Hummer's methods was used to synthesize graphite oxide, as described in previous studies [33]. Graphite oxide (70 mg) was taken in 150 mL round battle flask with 50 mL DW. The solution was sonication for 1 h to convert into graphene oxide (GO). Then 20 wt% of Pt(C2H3O2)4 and 10 wt% of Pd(CH3COO)2 were added to GO and continuously stirred for 30 min under a magnetic stirrer and subsequent dropwise addition of 25 mL of ascorbic acid (AA) to the above solution and further continuous stirred for 30 min, followed by addition of KI at ambient temperature. Finally, the product was transferred into a stainless-steel autoclave and heat treated at 150 °C for 3 h. At last, the specimen was rinsed using C2H6O and DW after the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature and dried overnight at 80 °C. The dried sample was grained with a mortar pestle and collected. The same process was carried out for the synthesis of Pt/RGO, Pd/RGO, and PP@RGO for with and without KI, as illustrated in Fig. 1 . 2.3 Characterization techniques The characterization techniques details are given in the supporting information. 2.4 Working electrode preparation and electrochemical measurements All electrochemical experiments were carried out in a 3-electrode electrochemical cell at normal temperature connected to (CHI 6002 E, USA) model, Potentiostat. As the reference and counter electrodes, an Ag/AgCl & a Pt wire were utilized, respectively. The working electrode (WE) was created on a glassy carbon disk (GCE) with a geometric area of 0.0706 cm2 and a diameter of 3 mm. The GCE was first thoroughly polished with alumina powder 1.0, 0.5, and 0.05 μm before being repeatedly ultrasonicated in C2H6O and DW. Then, catalyst weighing 2 mg was dispersed in 500 μL of DW, 500 μL of C2H6O, and 10 mL of a 0.5 wt% percent Nafion solution using an ultrasonic dispersion method for 30 min. Before conducting the electrochemical experiments, 4 μL of the mixture was dropped casted on the GCE surface and allowed to air dry for 24 h. The electrode potential from −0.2 to 1.2 V versus Ag/AgCl at a scan rate of 50 mV/s for 20 cycles, cyclic voltammetry (CV) studies were carried out in N2-saturated 0.5 M H2SO4 solution. From the stable voltammograms, ECSA of catalyst were estimated. In this study, all potentials were conveyed against KCl that was saturated with Ag/AgCl. Chronoamperometric (CA) measurements were studied under applied potential of 0.62 V vs Ag/AgCl in 0.5 M H2SO4 & 1 M CH3OH. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 2 illustrates the crystalline phases of as-fabricated Pt/RGO, Pt/RGO-KI, Pd/RGO, Pd/RGO-KI, PP@RGO, and PP@RGO-KI electrocatalysts as determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. In Figs. 2a-b, prominent diffraction peaks at 39.87°, 46.53°, & 68.07° for Pt/RGO & Pd/RGO correspond to the (111), (200), and (220) crystalline planes of Pt and Pd NPs [34]. For the PP@RGO nanocomposite in Fig. 2c, the peak positions align with those of fcc Pt (JCPDF 04-0802) and Pd (JCPDS 46-1043), suggesting the formation of Pt-Pd NPs (PP NPs) with RGO sheet. The existence of the (111) diffraction peak at 39.87°, situated between the (111) peaks of Pt (39.79°) and Pd (39.80°), supports the synthesis of PP NPs on the RGO sheet, consistent with previous literature reports [35,36]. Similarly, Fig. 2d - f display XRD peaks for Pt/RGO-KI, Pd/RGO-KI, and PP@RGO-KI, attributed to diffraction from the (111), (200), and (220) planes, affirming the crystalline nature of the bimetallic nanocomposites. The bimetallic nanocomposite diffraction peaks exhibit clear distinctions between the Pt and Pd diffraction angles, providing evidence of PP@RGO formation. Further, the negative shift in the XRD peaks for PP/RGO and PP/RGO-KI suggests a strong interaction between Pt and Pd atoms, which is indicative of alloy formation. This alloying effect is known to modify the electronic structure and lattice parameters of the nanoparticles, leading to enhanced catalytic properties. The addition of KI during synthesis enhances the diffraction peak intensity, indicative of improved crystalline structure. Calculations of average crystallite size (D) using the Debye-Scherer equation (Eq. (1)) [37]. (1) D = (0.9 λ)/(β Cos θ) (nm) The symbols λ, β, and θ represent the X-ray radiation wavelengths used (with Cu ka = 0.154056 nm), the Bragg diffraction angle, and the peak's full-width-at-half maximum (FWHM), respectively. In here, it is revealed that KI influences the crystalline size of the synthesized materials. The Pt/RGO with and without KI exhibits average crystalline sizes of approximately 2.13 and 9.17 nm, respectively, while Pd/RGO shows sizes of 7.16 and 11.21 nm with and without KI. PP@RGO with and without KI demonstrates sizes of about 3.74 and 7.76 nm. Notably, the average crystalline size of PP@RGO with and without KI is comparable to that of Pt and Pd electrode materials, suggesting the influence of KI on crystalline size. Fig. 3 presents TEM micrographs illustrating the size, shape, & structure of the fabricated samples, namely PP@RGO & PP@RGO-KI. In Figs. 3a-b, it is evident that PP NPs agglomerate on the RGO surface, forming some spherical structures. The magnified TEM image in Fig. 3c reveals strong doping of metal nanoparticles within the RGO sheet. The standard particle size of the PP@RGO nanocomposite is ∼ 9.38 nm, with a d-spacing of ∼ 0.159 nm. The RGO sheet exhibits a wrinkled shape, with larger and darker regions likely corresponding to Pt or Pt-Pd nanoparticles and smaller, lighter regions attributed to Pd nanoparticles. Similarly, TEM micrographs for PP@RGO-KI Figures3d-f, show homogeneously dispersed PP NPs without pronounced agglomeration compared to PP@RGO. In PP@RGO-KI, the particle size is around 12.42 nm, with a d-spacing value of ∼ 0.225 nm, corresponding to (111) lattice spacing of fcc-Pt and Pd. The inset images in Figs. 3c-f demonstrate the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns for both PP@RGO & PP@RGO-KI. The SAED pattern for PP@RGO-KI indicates better crystallinity compared to PP@RGO, crucial for electrocatalytic performance. TEM studies were performed on both PP/RGO and PP/RGO-KI after electrochemical measurements and presented in Fig. 4 . It is evident from the analysis that in the case of PP/RGO a small extent of aggregation is observed after electrochemical tests. However, no morphological changes were observed in the case of PP/RGO-KI after electrochemical tests implying advantage of KI usage in the preparation of the catalyst for achieving better electrochemical stability. Furthermore, Fig. 5 depicts energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrometry results to quantify the atomic composition of the catalyst. The EDX spectra reveal peaks for Pt, Pd, and C, confirming the presence of PP NPs on the RGO sheet. The EDS maps provide additional evidence of the consistent spreading of PP NPs on the RGO thin sheet throughout the catalyst surface. Further to find accurate composition of Pt and Pd on catalyst and prepared material was measured using ICP-OES. The results revealed 19.5 wt% Pt on RGO (Pt/RGO), 19.6 wt% Pd on RGO (Pd/RGO), 19.6 wt% Pt + 9.7 wt% Pd on RGO (PP@RGO), and 19.7 wt% Pt + 9.6 wt% Pd on RGO (PP@RGO-KI) catalysts. Raman spectroscopy serves as a robust technique and an effective methodology for examining intercalation and structural defects in carbon-based materials. Fig. 6 illustrates the Raman spectra of the as-fabricated PP@RGO & PP@RGO-KI hybrid composites. In this context, the prominent D and G bands represent the breathing mode phonons of A1g in the 1200 to 1500 cm−1 range and the E2g phonon of sp2 hybridized carbon atoms in the 1500 to 1600 cm−1 range, respectively. The assessment of disorder degree and typical size of sp2 domains in few-layer graphene samples can be achieved by evaluating the ratio of D to G (ID/IG). Fig. 6, PP/RGO & PP@RGO-KI exhibit two broad bands centered at 1341 & 1338 cm−1 (D-bands) and 1584 & 1574 cm−1 (G-bands) [38]. These bands, indicative of low-order states of carbon atoms in sp3 (D-band) and sp2 (G-band) configurations, affirm the presence of graphene in the catalysts [39]. The calculated ID/IG values for PP@RGO & PP@RGO-KI electrodes are 0.846 and 0.849, respectively, signifying the reduction of GO to RGO. Significantly, adding KI to the PP@RGO sample causes the intensity of the D & G bands to significantly rise, indicating that the material's crystalline structure has been enhanced. Moreover, the XRD and HR-TEM micrographs also support this increased crystallinity. To achieve exceptional electrical conductivity in hybrid composites, such advancements are essential. Fig. 7 shows the surface elemental oxidization states and chemical composition of PP/RGO nanostructures examined by XPS, which determined the presence of platinum, palladium, carbon, and oxygen. Moreover, the deconvolution spectra of the elements will give strong evidence for the chemical composition of prepared materials. The enlarged spectra of C1s contain four peaks at 284.4, 285.2, 287.0, and 289.0 eV representing the CC, CO, OC-O, and OCO bonds. The high-resolution spectra of O1s represent two peaks at 532.5 and 537.0 eV determining the CO and –COOH bonds [40]. The deconvolution spectra of Pd 3d represent 6 peaks at 335.1, 335.6, 336.5, 340.5, 341.4, and 342.8 eV, the peaks at 335.6 and 340.5 eV assigned to the Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2 peaks of metallic Pd(0) and peaks at 336.5 and 342. 8 eV suggest the Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2 of metallic Pd2+ state and remaining peaks 335.1 and 341.4 were attributed to Pd/C peaks [41]. The enlarged spectra of Pt 4f suggest the four peaks at 71.2, 72.1, 74.6 and 75.4 eV, which represents the Pt 4f7/2 (74.6eV) and Pt 4f5/2 (71.2 eV) species of metallic Pt and peaks at 72.1eV (Pt 4f7/2) and 75.4 eV (Pt 4f5/2) represents the Pt2+ species [42,43]. The XPS results show the synthesized nanostructures have bimetallic PtPd with a trace amount of Pd2+ and Pt2+ ions coupled with carbon. Fig. 8 presents cyclic voltammograms (CVs) for hybrid composites synthesized in situ, encompassing commercially available Pt/C, Pd/RGO, Pt/RGO, PP@RGO, and PP@RGO-KI, in an N2-saturated 0.5 M H2SO4 solution. The CV experiments were conducted at a scan rate of 50 mV/s, while the electrode potential ranged from −0.2 to 1.2 V vs Ag/AgCl. To ensure the stability of the voltammograms, 20 cycles of potential scanning were performed before data collection. Due to methanol oxidation, all electrocatalysts displayed characteristic fine-separated anodic peaks across both forward as well as reverse scans [44,45]. Methanol adsorption was measured using freshly generated oxidation of chemisorbed species at 0.6 to 0.8 V. The reverse scan of the faradic oxidation of carbon-based species peak at 0.4 V was identified in all of the materials tested. Moreover, the CV cycles of all the examined electrocatalysts exhibit typical characteristics of the hydrogen adsorption (Hads)/deposition (Hdes) in a potential range from −0.2 < E < 0.05 vs Ag/AgCl (Hads ↔ H + + e −) [46]. Similarly, the formation of OHads takes place past 0.05 V (2H2O → OHads + H3O+ + e −) [47]. Here, the Hads & OHads refer to the accumulated hydrogen and the adsorbed OH species on the surface of the catalyst under study, respectively. In addition, the observed cathodic peaks at 0.4 V infer the reduction of Pd(II) oxide, which formed during the anodic reaction at 0.6 to 1.0 V on the surface of the catalyst. Here PP@RGO & PP@RGO-KI demonstrate outstanding catalytic activity as compared to other catalyst due to its high catalytic surface area. Moreover, the designated region pertains to the cumulative hydrogen adsorption charge and is computed after implementing a double-layer adjustment., as described in references. The following equation is used to calculate the ECSA of the catalysts [48]: ECSA = [QH-ads]/210 µC cm−2 × Pt-mass on GCE In contrast, the CV profile of a Pt/C catalyst, along with its corresponding ECSA value. The ECSA values for both the benchmark Pt/C and the fabricated nanocomposites exhibit the subsequent order of PP@RGO-KI (83.69 m2/g) > PP@RGO (78.73 m2/g) > Pt/RGO (62.94 m2/g) > Pt/C black (50.72 m2/g) > Pd/RGO (43.84 m2/g). The increased ECSA observed in PP@RGO-KI presumably results from the more uniform distribution and smaller particle size of PP NPs on the RGO sheets, as verified by HR-TEM analyses. The CV outcomes demonstrate enhanced electron transport across the electrode surface and an improved number of catalytic active sites for electrochemical reactions in PP@RGO-KI nanocomposite catalyst [49]. In light of this, one can expect that the nanocomposite electrocatalyst PP@RGO-KI will demonstrate superior electrocatalytic performance in methanol oxidation in contrast to commercially available Pt/C catalysts and PP@RGO, Pt/RGO, & Pd/RGO. The electrocatalytic characteristics of both benchmark electrode Pt/C and in-house-synthesized nanocomposites for MOR were thoroughly examined using CV in a 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte containing 1.0 M CH3OH, as depicted in Fig. 9 a-b. Each catalyst exhibited distinct anodic peaks in both forward & reverse scans, indicating the occurrence of the methanol oxidation process. The appearance of a peak in the 0.6 to 0.8 V range is attributed to the oxidation of species recently absorbed from CH3OH [50]. Conversely, the reverse scan is associated with the faradic oxidation of carbonaceous compounds remaining from the preceding forward scan [51]. In Fig. 9c, demonstrates the detailed analysis of the methanol electro-oxidation performance of the as synthesized nanocomposites, comparing them with commercial Pt/C catalyst. The evaluation considers both mass-normalized current and specific area current density. Mass-normalized current densities (jmass) at 0.631 V were determined for various catalysts, resulting in values of 0.131, 0.171, 0.215, 0.421, and 0.526 mA/μg-Pt for Pd/RGO, Pt/C, Pt/RGO, PP@RGO, & PP@RGO-KI, respectively. Additionally, the specific area current densities (jspecific) at the same voltage were measured as 0.298, 0.337, 0.341, 0.534, and 0.628 mA/cm² for Pd/RGO, Pt/C, Pt/RGO, PP@RGO, and PP@RGO-KI, respectively. The evaluation of methanol oxidation activity involves considering an additional parameter ratio, denoted as If/Ib, which represents the difference between the forward (If) and backward (Ib) peak current density [52]. A higher If/Ib ratio indicates a reduced presence of species that poison the catalyst's surface, suggesting increased efficiency in methanol oxidation. In this context, the observed If/Ib values were as follows: PP@RGO-KI (1.72) > PP@RGO (1.54) > Pt/RGO (1.04) > Pt/C (1.01) > Pd/RGO (0.89), indicating that PP@RGO-KI is more effective in mitigating surface poisoning effects [53]. The electrocatalytic activity of the fabricated PP@RGO-KI demonstrates an ∼ 2-to-3-fold increase compared to the benchmark Pt/C electrode. This improved catalytic activity can be attributed to various factors. Firstly, there is a larger ECSA, facilitated by the uniform distribution of PP NPs on the exterior of graphene. This allocation enhances electron mobility and expands the overall surface area of graphene [54]. Furthermore, the inclusion of Pd, a metal with higher oxophilicity compared to Pt, aids in the oxidative removal of CO on Pt, leveraging the high reactivity of nanoscale palladium in CO oxidation. Additionally, Pd has the capacity to modify the electronic configuration of Pt, thereby weakening the strength of the Pt–CO bond and streamlining the process of CO elimination [55]. It is crucial to highlight that the presence of O2-containing functional groups on RGO surface can enhance the catalyst resilience against CO-induced deactivation [56]. In the PP@RGO-KI catalyst, graphene plays a substantial role in eliminating CO-like species, contributing to its elevated electrocatalytic activity for methanol oxidation. Chronoamperometry (CA) tests were conducted for 1000 s. to assess the endurance of the electrocatalysts in a mixture of 0.5 M H2SO4 & 1.0 M CH3OH saturated with N2 at 0.6 V, as illustrated in Fig. 9d. Initially, all electrocatalysts exhibited a pronounced decline in current attributed to the adsorption of CO-like species. Subsequently, the system stabilized. In contrast to Pt/C, Pt/RGO, Pd/RGO, & PP@RGO, the PP@RGO-KI catalyst, synthesized in its pristine state, consistently maintained a stable and elevated current density over the entire 1000-sec. duration. This demonstrates its superior efficacy and sustained performance in the realm of methanol oxidation. The increased activity of the PP@RGO-KI nanocomposite can be ascribed to its reduced size and the synergistic benefits derived from its Pt, Pd, and RGO constituents. Nanocomposites of PP@RGO-KI, synthesized in the presence of KI, exhibit a more constant dispersion with less agglomeration on the RGO [57]. This characteristic enhances the accessibility of Pt–Pd sites, resulting in more efficient catalytic activity compared to PP@RGO. These findings strongly indicate that the PP@RGO-KI electrocatalyst surpasses the performance of other nanocomposites, including PP@RGO, Pt/RGO, Pd/RGO, and Pt/C, as supported by voltametric measurements. In summary, electrochemical results underscore the efficacy of the PP@RGO-KI bimetallic nanocomposite, prepared utilizing a halide-assisted approach, making it a promising candidate for DMFC applications as a suitable anode catalyst. 4 Conclusion In this work, a novel hybrid nanocomposite comprising of PP NPs accumulated on RGO, with and without the addition of KI, was fabricated using a distinctive chemical reduction-assisted hydrothermal approach in the presence of AA. This composite was employed for the MOR process. The PP@RGO-KI nanocomposite demonstrated significantly enhanced electrocatalytic activity and stability when compared to PP@RGO, Pt/RGO, Pd/RGO, & Pt/C electrodes for the MOR. Notably, it achieved a superior mass activity of 0.526 mA/µg-Pt, specific area current densities (jspecific) of 0.628 mA/cm², and an oxidation peak current to reduction peak current ratio (If/Ib) of 1.72. The improved performance of PP@RGO-KI electrocatalyst can be ascribed to the larger ECSA value, abundant active sites, and bimetallic synergistic effects between Pt & Pd NPs. Furthermore, the use of RGO ensures high electrical conductivity, facilitating rapid electron transfer between the catalyst and electrolyte solution. Consequently, this study presents an effective demonstration of hybrid composite fabrication to enhance the electrocatalytic performance of fuel cells. The key findings emphasize the superior performance of PP@RGO-KI compared to other catalysts tested, as indicated by higher mass-normalized and specific current densities. The synergistic effects between Pt and Pd nanoparticles, along with enhanced electron transfer facilitated by RGO, contribute to its effectiveness. Furthermore, the high If/Ib value of PP@RGO-KI highlights its ability to reduce surface poisoning during methanol oxidation. The study also underscores the eco-friendly synthesis approach, using a single-step chemical reduction strategy with ascorbic acid, which supports scalable and sustainable production methods. Overall, the results point to the significant potential of PP@RGO-KI in advancing the efficiency and practicality of DMFCs, marking a substantial step towards cleaner energy solutions. coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalytic oxidation of methanol is crucial for the transition to clean energy and the effective utilization of renewable sources. The strategy to develop efficient electrocatalysts with improved efficiency and durability for the methanol oxidation (MOR) reaction is essential to enable the widespread usage of direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs). This research proposes a novel, eco-friendly single-step procedure for preparing a highly efficient bimetallic platinum-palladium (Pt-Pd)/reduced graphene oxide-potassium iodide (RGO-KI) (PP@RGO-KI) nanocomposite sheet for electrocatalytic methanol oxidation. The method employs a chemical reduction strategy via a hydrothermal reaction, utilizing ascorbic acid (AA) as a simple and green reducing agent. The synergistic effects of Pt and Pd nanoparticles, along with enhanced electron transfer enabled by RGO, were examined by calculating the mass-normalized current densities (jmass) at 0.631 V for Pt/C, Pd/RGO, Pt-Pd/RGO (PP@RGO), Pt/RGO & PP@rGO-KI were 0.131, 0.171, 0.215, 0.421, and 0.526 mA/µg-Pt, respectively. Furthermore, the specific current densities (jspecific) at 0.631 V were determined as follows: 0.298 mA/cm² for Pd/RGO, 0.337 mA/cm² for Pt/C, 0.341 mA/cm² for Pt/RGO, 0.534 mA/cm² for PP@RGO, and 0.628 mA/cm² for PP@RGO-KI. In additionally, the If/Ib values exhibited the following trend: PP@RGO-KI (1.72) > PP@RGO (1.54) > Pt/RGO (1.04) > Pt/C (1.01) > Pd/RGO (0.89), signifying that PP@RGO-KI is effective in preventing surface poisoning effects. The excellent electrocatalytic efficiency of the PP@RGO-KI, coupled with its facile and rapid manufacturing method, suggests significant potential for advancing DMFCs.
